title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Tak yin o' my pistols, forI'll never miss it. And see, gin ye tak my advice and gin ye're gaun toBarns, gang off the Peebles road at Leadburn, and haud doun by theBrochtoun and Newlands ways, for a' the way atween Leadburn and Peeblesis hotchin' wi' sodgers and what-ye-may-ca'-thems. Guid e'en to ye, anda safe journey."

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: One--theway by which I had gone when I set out on my travels--goes over the moorand down by the springs of the Eddleston Water, through the village ofthat name, and thence down the vale to Peebles. The other, longer andmore circuitous, cuts straight over the rough moorlands to the littlevillage of Newlands, then over much wild country to Kirkurd, and thehigh hills which hem in the hamlet of Broughton, whence it is but fivemiles to the house of Dawyck. It is a road which I have always hated asbeing dismal and wild beyond any of my knowledge, but now I was glad tobe on it, for every step brought me nearer to my love.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "Quaite quaite, smith," muttered Robin Sheil of the Newlands on this occasion. "Here's Strong Mac doon frae the muirs wi' a job for ye! An' ye had better no* even Chairlie Webster wi' the Dominie's lass in his hearin' !"

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance

Guid e'en to ye, anda safe journey."

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat. Tales, chiefly of Galloway, gathered from the years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: The children had a nurse, Meysie Dickson, a girl whowas already a woman in staidness and steadfastness atfifteen. She had been in a kind of half-hearted way engagedto be married to Weelum Lammitter, the grieve atNewlands ; but when the two bairns were left on her hand,she told Weelum that he had better take Kirst Laurie,which Weelum Lammitter promptly did. title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: The children had a nurse, Meysie Dickson, a girl who was already a womanin staidness and steadfastness at fifteen. She had been in a kind ofhalf-hearted way engaged to be married to Weelum Lammitter, the grieveat Newlands; but when the two bairns were left on her hand, she toldWeelum that he had better take Kirst Laurie, which Weelum Lammitterpromptly did. There was a furnished house attached to the grieveship,and he could not let it stand empty any longer.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Population 3147. Newlands, a parish of Scotland, in thecounty of Peebles, situated on the bordersof Mid-Lothian, and containing 1300 Scotsacres. Population 1163.

title: Bog-Myrtle and Peat; Tales Chiefly of Galloway Gathered from the Years 1889 to 1895
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: The children had a nurse, Meysie Dickson, a girl who was already a womanin staidness and steadfastness at fifteen. She had been in a kind ofhalf-hearted way engaged to be married to Weelum Lammitter, the grieveat Newlands; but when the two bairns were left on her hand, she toldWeelum that he had better take Kirst Laurie, which Weelum Lammitterpromptly did. There was a furnished house attached to the grieveship,and he could not let it stand empty any longer.

title: Rambles in Europe ... With historical facts relating to Scotch-American families, gathered in Scotland and the North of Ireland ... Illustrated
author: Morrison, Leonard Allison.
snippet: Before reaching the "Hermitage" we halted atthe house of the gamekeeper at Newlands, andprocured the key. The castle, built in 1244, standson a slight elevation, near the highway.

title: Rambles in Europe:
author: Morrison, Leonard Allison
snippet: Before reaching- the " Hermitao;e " we halted at the house of the gamekeeper at Newlands, and procured the key. The castle, built in 1244, stands on a sHght elevation, near the highway.
